item.title: Overcome Social Anxiety
item.description:
Look at others and just look/focus at one person at a time (even if speaking to a group).


So you see what others thinking and are not focused on yourself!
If you don't know anything (e.g. not even to introduce yourself), you need to visit a behavioural therapy :)

Just focus on one person, that is easier and nearly everybody can do that (a 1 on 1 talk).

item.title: Say no politely
item.description:
Denying requests opens up your time/resources to say yes to the right opportunities.
Built your (little) world to say yes to the right things.


If you don't have time for something, at least let the other person know it.
e.g.
Unfortunately, at the moment I don't have time to help you with this project.
I hope you find someone else to support you.

E.g. with
Thank you for understanding.

Some formulations you want to use to be kind & polite:

Thank you for thinking of me.
Sounds like a great project/event/idea, but this is not for us.
I don't have enough time on my plate to offer you quality help.
"Sadly" or "unfortunately"


Refer them to somebody else
Say how long you are not available
With a "I reach out, when I have time", you can decide when you want a further collaboration

item.title: Atomic habits
item.description:
Noticing
plan exacetly when you do what
plan for failure (failure premortem)
think about why you failed your most important goal in 6 months
then improve it and make a plan to tackle possible pitfalls
not enough time for the workout on monday at 7pm => do it on Tuesday 6:30am
Wanting
shape your physical environment => make good decisions easy, and bad difficult
make "bad" habits more difficult
in nearly all living rooms, the couches and chairs face the TV, so it is designed to watch TV => instead let the chairs face e.g. a table with a book on it
hide the TV behind something (e.g. set it in the wall behind a "door")
unplug all cables of the TV and just plug them in, when you can say what you want to watch
e.g. don't switch on PC if its quite likely to be just gaming/watching unnecessary videos (not related to the physical environment, but still a good tip ;) )
make "good" habits easier
e.g. putting books in places I see them often
Doing
plan for the start not the finishing line
just start
get repetition
scale habits down to 2 minutes per repetition
reading books => read one page
put on running shoes, step out the door, lock it, go back in
start VSC, open project, read a little bit, shut it down again
=> master the art of showing up (you become the type of person who does it)
=> habit must be established (new normal), before it can be improved
too focues on optimizing, than first establishing habit
right actions leads to the right results anyways
you become somebody through action
e.g. every time you write you are an writer
you stenghten your belief about your identity to be somebody (e.g. being studious when you learn Spanish once a week)
Liking
reward yourself now to be motivated
problem: most good habits have the reward in the future
solutions
hang up a calendar and cross each day you do the habit => now it is about not breaking the chain! blank-calendar-template.png
have 90 red and 10 blue marble
each time you do the habit, you take one marble out
red one => good job, you did your habit
blue one => you do something really fun/cool (e.g. play a game, go out do sports, meet with friends)
surprising and possibly very nice experience


little moments decide over a lot of time
e.g. if I start Windows I am going to game
but if I start Ubuntu, I am much more likely to be productive
that also means, that we don't have to change a lot, to be much more the person we want to become
can be helped (to get the right entry points) through properly arranging environment, doing it with others, ...
join a group where your wanted behaviour is the normal behaviour

item.title: Flow
item.description:
#flow #focus #learning
tags: #flow #focus #learning
overview: if it is a subtopic to a broader topic like a summary note of notes
related:
sources: Limitless

summary



Remove all distractions: You need to fully focus
Take/Schedule some time for it: Around 90'-120'
Know why you want it: Set (best write down) a clear goal
Goal should be a little challenging


Multitasking
Fear/pressure/...: Do important and urgent tasks first. Have a protecting shield, like a super hero, against everything else for full focus.
Fear of failure/Perfectionism: Missing persuasion about flow or aim


"Fight": E.g. research, work-out: Probably won't feel like flow in the beginning.
Break: Take a walk, breathing exercises, ...
Flow: "Hero"-/"Superhuman"-phase
After flow: (short) break until the next flow could be come again, the low until the next high


Extreme increace in productivity: around 5x
Great feeling: motivational boost

item.title: Focus
item.description:
#remarkN #remarkN


If there is a thought for example while reading and it is important but not urgent, just take a note. This way for the brain it is done and can focus again on the task at hand.
Don't try to just not think about it.


commit to sth. ( #remarkN Still struggling with it so here once again: You cannot be really good in a lot of things, FOCUS)
reject alternative & distractions joy of missing out
increased opportunity ( #remarkN at least in this field bc. greater network and deeper in it)
freedom & liberation in commitment bc. no longer distracted, full attention
knowing what you have is already good enough; why stress about chasing more and more More is not always better
Gold is hidden in depth

item.title: Habit
item.description:
#habit #powerful
tags: #habit #powerful
overview: if it is a subtopic to a broader topic like a summary note of notes
related:
sources: Limitless

Use habits to your advantage. Build positive ones to get the most out of every day.

Habit is either the best of all servants or the worst of all bosses.
- Nathaniel Emmens

Habits are important and very strong.


That the theory according to Foggs

Motivation: Why do you want to change it or stop with something? You need a strong reason, otherwise it won't work.
Ability: Do you have the time, money, resources to do it?
Trigger: How you change it and with what it is replaced.

Replace a bad habit, the time or what you do, with a good one.
E.g. Your aim is to stop watching YouTube. Then you should have a plan for what to do instead, otherwise you just fall into your old/bad routine. You could set the goal to read for one hour when you come home (instead of watching YouTube).

item.title: How habits work
item.description:
It's a cycle of trigger, craving, reaction and award.


First there is a situation to change/solve e.g. a dark room.

You want to see something, so you want to light the room.

You react accordingly to get what you want by switching on the light.

In the end you get the reward for your routine: You see something!

item.title: Improvements
item.description:
1% better each day 1.01^365 = 31.18 0.99^365 = 0.03
change mindset => to change actions => to change results

item.title: Make habits stick
item.description:
Have fun ;)
Accountability partner
motivation
pushing forward
Control your environment
posts
count days (done)
reminders
prepare clothes day/night before
...
Boundaries/rules
every second day
...
build new habits on already existing ones How habits work
f.e. when i make my cup of tea i meditate for 60 sec.
making cup of tea (trigger) => meditating (routing) => cup of tea => reward

item.title: Notes taking
item.description:
Take notes and create notes by asking yourself questions about the usefulness of the taken notes and how you can connect this new thing to other learned things. Create and use to remember it.



Think: Even before you have to take notes, e.g. before a lecture or a book, be clear what you want to get out, what is your aim with the notes later.
Identify: During the notes taking process, find out what is (most) helpful for you aim.
Prioritise: After go over your notes again and highlight the most important things or summarise them.

Why do you take notes? That is an important questions because the answer determines also the approach. In most cases we want to remember the information for a long time. But it is also very likely that we won't remember everything just after gaining the information for the first time and taking notes. So we also have to take notes in a way that we can later review them and learn or better remember more of it.
So we take notes to group and connect the new information in a way we understand them better. And to have a fundament for further learning.

Divide e.g. your sheet into two columns. On the one side just take notes. On the other side get creative and create notes yourself connected to your taken notes.

Best practice is to group notes by subject. If there are sub-subjects just indent.
Don't transcript what you e.g. hear. That is not efficient for remembering or using them later. Prioritise.

Learning a complex but high efficient abbreviations system could take too long and would be another challenge. By creating your own ones, you can always adapt what you abbreviate and create them on your own.
For a topic where a long word e.g. artificial intelligent => AI is used often you can make your own abbreviation and just put a post it (or write it down at the beginning or end of this section) with the abbreviation on your notes to remember what it meant later on.

In the create notes column, you should deepen the learned things.
Not limited but standard questions for creating notes can be:

How can I use this?
Why must I use this?
When will I use this?

It is better to not take (too much) notes while listening or reading. You don't and should not write everything down, but just enough to remember when it is a presentation, or even pause the video/audiobook or close the book before taking notes.
That way you really focus on the information input first and are not disctracted by note taking. Afterwards you do active recalling and your brain has to review/remember it again. This is especially important for getting it to the long term memory.

After the e.g. lecture or section of book review your notes, because the memory of it is still fresh and maybe you want to add or change some things.

Even take and create notes on fictional topics to keep you practice this skill and test your comprehenions on reading/listening/...

There are two main approaches:

By hand you can take notes more freely and e.g. draw things.
By typing (e.g. on a laptop) you are (probably) faster and write nicer.
Today we have the opportunity to have the best of two worlds with a tablet.

item.title: Reward
item.description: Looking forwards to something, gives you a better feeling than the actual reward. Quite weird^^

item.title: Think positive
item.description:
#disclaimerN #remarkN
#disclaimerN regarding 12 rules for life: topic about treating yourself as you would treat somebody you are responsible for

Thinking positive (especially about yourself) contributes to faster learning and a better health.


Am I really that bad as I always say/think? How many of my bad performances are just talked into me?

Means "Limited Idea Entertained" and groups all ideas that are limiting you. For example for a long time it was believed that an human cannot run a mile under 4 minutes. But when it was broken once, a lot of people did it.
Discard limiting ideas. And create new true beliefs by finding real evidence. E.g. everytime I did a presentation, was it really bad? Did the audience throw bad vegetables? Or did they applause and somebody said it was really good afterwards?

Unfortunately there is not enough ant spray against all these Automatic Negative Thought(s).

Make your inner critic hilarious. That has two purposes

differentiate it from "your own self" ( #remarkN I would say, it is a part of one self, on the other hand we are indeed able to "battle" ourselfes or have different positions. Often times, as life is, it is not one sided and we have hypocritical opinions)
easier to surpress

Positive thoughts opens the mind.

When a tiger hunts us, we just focus on escaping. Today there are a lot of these "tigers" and that limits us.

And in these situation, it is even less helpful, if one blames about oneself. Instead work on the solution.

Are very powerful words.
What comes after has a very powerful impact. Because we want to conform to our ideals. It has a great potenzial for motivation.

Remembering and repeating learned information without looking at your notes.



structures information
improves diagnostic value (makes new/more connections to valuable information)

It uses a lot of brain power. Therefor you can get lazy and then just reread the solution, instead of active recalling it.

Walk! With that you have more bloodflow and are more active, so you don't get tired too fast.
And of course take brakes (e.g. Pomodoro Technique, drink enough, ...

item.title: juggling
item.description:
#HowTo
#HowTo


be really good in juggling with two balls in each hand
juggle with two in one hand + just do the movement of throwing with your second hand (with or without the ball, but without throwing it) => train to have both hands do something while juggling with at least one
(if you didn't already) do exercise from 2. and look straight in front (not on the side where your juggling) => get accustomed to look in between the "juggling sides" (two balls on each side)
practice more
try flashes (just throwing up all four balls once and catch all)
practice more
now you can start juggling with all four at the same time
done :)

item.title: Language Learning
item.description:
#language #learning #video #video #video
tags: #language #learning
related:
sources:

#video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ke9ki4Fdqkc
#video How I am studying 4 languages (Spanish, Russian, Korean, Mandarin)
#video Learn a new language in one week
Limitless
Learn languages efficient, especially in the beginning to motivate yourself.



talk direct or over phone
chat
write letters


phone language
search things
think
hear a lot
even the beginning to get in touch with it


Learn most used words first

Make it rememberable by creating stories with the new word and the meaning in your native language. That way you have a visualization, maybe an emotion and an connection between the native and we created something (a story with all these connections), therefor we remember it even better.
If the language has different gender for nouns, you can built in specific "things" to connect to e.g. the feminine nouns by always having e.g. a skirt in the story.
E.g.:

Regenschirm --> le parabluie: "Auf einer Parade hat ein Pl√ºschtier mit Hut einen aufgespannten Regenschirm." (The cuddle toy has a hat, because it is masculine)
Wolke --> cloud: "Sehen sie, wie ein Riese eine Wolke klaut."

go for the long tearm goal (a year) to really seeing progress


Eggbun: for Korean and Japanese; by writing to a char robot which does certain (limited) exercises with you
Eggbun (Apple app store): Chat to learn Japanese
Eggbun (Web): chat to learn Korean

item.title: Learn the most used words first
item.description:
#language #learning #frequency #video
tags: #language #learning #frequency
overview: Language Learning
related:
sources: #video The fastest way to learn a new language: The solar system theory

Learn the most frequently used words in a language first. That way you boost how much you learn tremendiously because you also use it the most (in this language).


To get going, the best way is to learn the most frequent words (and word compositions) first. That way your learning curve is far steeper and you have more motivation to go on.
The specific 10% or 20% of words you use the most not just differ from language to language but also from person to person with different interest. That doesn't mean you should spend hours on figuring out what words you use the often.
But the really most used words e.g. "and" or "the" in English you should learn first. For nearly any language there are already some lists, apps or websites that can help with that.

And it is also just more efficient. Like always the 80/20 rule also applies here.

item.title: Investing in shares
item.description:
#Investing
tags: #Investing
overview: if it is a subtopic to a broader topic like a summary note of notes
related: Investing
sources: "a relative"

Investing in shares is not always/just easy.


How to know what and when to buy? There are different options to estimate the value and the "future" of a share:

With numbers e.g. P/I (If a company really makes profit and is worth what a share costs)
Graphs: What is the current trend?
Questions: Ask yourself: What do they people need? What do I need and like?
E.g. Apple: Functions gread and makes my life easiere --> good company :)
Coco: Coconut water will be especially valuable when there is water shortage

You can make a profit either through the increase in value or the dividens a company pays you. It is good to know the difference and have some of both.

Invest shares in different sectors e.g. technical, pharmaceutical, food, ...
That is important bc. if one sector is performing bad, probably others will do better.

item.title: Investing
item.description:
Today investing is all about making the highest financial ROI. This page is all about that. Even though I know, this system has big issues (socially and ecologically)


Have different categories to invest in: Shares, (noble) metals, real estate, ...

Know before when to leave in a trade (in the positive and negative). Otherwise you could act emotionally which is very bad (for you at least^^).

Also count with the fees a trade costs you. E.g. maybe you don't just have in the plus to make a profit but when paid 5 euros in fee, the share has to rise higher than that before you even make profit. So sometimes a trade is not worth it due to fees.

item.title: Incremental reading
item.description:
#reading #learning #speedreading #wikipedia
tags: #reading #learning #speedreading
overview: if it is a subtopic to a broader topic like a summary note of notes
related: Speed reading Notes taking
sources: #wikipedia Incremental Reading

Make flashcards with topics and questions about a read subject. These flashcards are then reviewed after some time to keep the information for a life.


To make these flashcards you have to determine what information is important to you (in that moment) and then write these subjects and/or questions about it to thing or answer in a later stage.
This is the creating process where you have to first take apart what information is in a e.g. text. Then figure out what you want to remember of it. And then ask the right questions about it.

To remember wanted information you also have to review the cards after a set time period.

item.title: Remember Dreams
item.description:
#dream #morning
tags: #dream #morning
overview: if it is a subtopic to a broader topic like a summary note of notes
related:
sources: Limitless (part of Jim Kwik's morning routine)

The DREAMS technique for remembering dreams. It is helpful to reflect them and talk about it to others for creativity and what's going on in your life.


Best to do it right after you wake up, to remember most.

Decide to want to remember your dream(s).

Write down what you can remember

With closed eyes, your ability to remember is better.

Decide conciously to remember it.

Sleep management and routine.

Talk with others about it. It's similar to teaching, with sharing you remember it better.

item.title: Remember names
item.description:
#remember #name #book
tags: #remember #name
overview: if it is a subtopic to a broader topic like a summary note of notes
related:
sources: #book Limitless

Use the name yourself and try to connect it with a lot of things to strengthen the memory of it.



Always
Believe: that you are good in remembering names
Exercise: every time you hear/see a new name, try to remember it e.g. when meeting sb. or just in a video
When meeting
Say: the name e.g. "Oh nice to meet you XY."
Use: the name in a possible following conversation
Ask: what origin the name has, so you connect more things with the name
Visualize: assoziate an image with the name/person
End: the meeting with saying the name again

item.title: Gamification
item.description:
#video
#video The 4 Gamification Techniques



reward <-> punishment
generally nobody pays you to play games



autonomy: the choices people make and why they make them
competence: ability to be challenged appropriately
relatedness: our connection and support to others => development and maintenance of close, personal relationships

Flow

full immersed/focused
great control
distortion of time


clear goal that you are working towards
see the progress you are doing to reach that goal
balance of the challenge and your skill
clear and immediate feedback how you are doing in achievieng that goal


goals to reach
rules: how we can reach the goals
make the game more interesting e.g. handball would be much easier if you are allowed to take as many steps as you want with the ball
challenge/conflict: that come up from that combination of goals and rules
feedback

When you want to motivate people and have more engagement.

item.title: How to excel at Math and Science
item.description:
#video #book
#video How to Excel at Math and Science about the #book "A Mind for Number - How to excel at Math and Science"


Focus mode: focusing on one task/problem
Diffuse mode: coming up with different solutions (in the background)


if one already has a solution, it is much more difficult to find a better one/think of other solutions


first focus on a thing (e.g. learging)
if one is stuck, take a break and "distract yourself" (e.g. sports, sleep, shower, walk) --> brain is working on the problem in the background and you may find the solution quicker
for that to work, you have to know the basics of the problem (if you don't understand it at all, you most likely won't understand it later either...)


learning every day a little bit (you cannot either gain muscles in a week)
recalling is the best way
read and then think/recall it (e.g. closing the book you've just read)



attempting problem
reading solution
"Oh I now know it" --> one doesn't :(


understand basics: ask (friend, teacher), read about it
attempt problem and work it completely through
solution was needed: work problem through again and not only know what to do but also WHY, to make it work on different problems too and make new brain connections
solution was not needed: perfect, congratulation, go on to next problem
after a time (solving problems, at least one) take a break (--> get into diffuse mode, to let brain process the new thoughts)
practice lots of problems


go on, if you have successfully solved a problem without the solution (of couse best to do 1-2, but maybe, as the recalling technique, make another related problem later)
mix up problems (e.g. don't just do some of a section, because in the test, they won't be divided into sections either)


do the difficult/unwanted task right in the morning or/and after coming home (e.g. from school) to keep up/have the momentum


know (e.g. write down, hang on an image/material) why you do it
picture oneself after the done work


take your time to really understand e.g. the problem and how to apply it instead of just solving it, maybe even with the solution


setting timer also simulates a time pressure (as in an exam)


patient persistance is very important (learning curve is not linear) --> gets more fun, if you get better ;)
learn how to learn with the techniques above
mindset (shift) can help/is quite important
item.guid: LearningSkills/Productivity/How to excel at Math and Science.md

item.title: How to stay consistent
item.description:
#video #video #book #book
#video source: How I studied 12 hours a day over a year

build drive (motivation is quite useless)
growth mindset #video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pN34FNbOKXc
get good habits and track them
#book "Atomic Habits" by James Clear
#book "Deep Work" by Cal Newpost
high quality work = time spent * quality of focus
quality of focus/depth more important bc. depth can be improved more than the time (24 hours a day...)

item.title: Motivation
item.description:
#motivation
tags: #motivation
overview: if it is a subtopic to a broader topic like a summary note of notes
related: motivation for me media/videos/Build Success Without Discipline or Motivation media/videos/Let Your Pain Motivate You
sources:

Motivation is not just there. It is produced.


According to Jim Kwik, author of Limitless, the formula is
Purpose X Energy X S^3 = Motivation where
S^3 = Small simple steps


Meet The Billionaire that Works a Normal Job
listened to a lot of motivational speeches (when he was young and started the business)

item.title: Not to-dos
item.description:
Don't work hard just to work hard
Work hard because your goals "demand" it
Don't wander aimlessly
focus on the goal
Don't worry about the outcome
improve every day and think about the steps not the outcome
Don't say yes
say no => to focus on some things not on (too) many
life has an end, it is restricted
value your time!

item.title: Pomodoro Technique
item.description:
#learning #system
tags: #learning #system
overview: if it is a subtopic to a broader topic like a summary note of notes
related:
sources: Limitless The Primacy/Recency Effect

25 minutes of work followed by a 5 minute break. Break should consist of walking, meditating, ....


Our natural concentraion span is between 10 - 40 minutes.

Things at the beginning and in the end of a session are remembered more often. This is called the Primary/Recency effect.

especially important for perfectionst (as I consider myself)
to better focus first on the important and then expand if needed/wanted
then take small and consistent steps to reach it


set a clear goal
write down, why (vision) and what it gives to me/others
What do I need for it?
Write down, what could go wrong? And then how I could prohibit it.
set and end date (with possible goals/dates in between) with a signature (like a contract)

item.title: SMART goal setting
item.description:
#goal #smart #disclaimerN
tags: #goal #smart
overview: if it is a subtopic to a broader topic like a summary note of notes
related: reach goals goal
sources:
#disclaimerN : In this document Start Finishing SMART is defined a little bit different.

Your target should be specific.
E.g. not just "be rich" but an exact amount, you want to achieve.

You should be able to measure your progress or subgoals.
E.g. don't just "be fit" but rather "be able to run a kilometre in 3 minutes".

Set subgoals to have motivation and be able to better see your progress made along the way.

Set realistic goals and also count in your environment and starting point/possibilites.

With time targets its more likely you achieve something.

item.title: Speed reading
item.description:
Is about the ability to read and understand text really fast.
It is an ability you can learn and train which has a lot of upside to other areas.


According to Michel Wozniak because in speed reading you can flexibly alter your speed. So it is not just going always faster, but controlling the pace: Have the ability to go quite fast, and still understand a lot, but sometimes slow down to get some tricky sentences, too.

Unlearn bad habits/techniques you learned in primary school

Regression: Jump back to parts of the text you already read
Subvocalize:
Get slower to understand more


Less understanding: When reading faster, your brain has more input and cannot wander away as easily as when reading slow. So you don't lose focus.
More difficult/stressful: You already have more practice (speed reading needs practice!) and you are faster finished with a given text.
Not valued: Because your control the pace, you can go faster on difficult/important passages.


Practice a lot: It needs a lot of practice to improve.
Stop subvocalizing: Stop with speaking or moving your physical vocal parts while reading (Just around 120 wpm). Mental subvocalizing can be helpful for understanding, but it also slows you down.
Solution: For vocal parts just take something in your mouth while speaking. For mentally subvocalizing you can count (e.g. one, two, three, one, ...), which can be distracting, or tab with your fingers. Tabbing with finger has the downside, that you "lose" one hand (so you cannot hold the book and use the other hand to guide your eyes anymore).
Guide the eyes: Guiding the eyes with e.g. your finger or a pen is crucial.
It helps with not jumping back (your eyes want to stay on the moving object), holding the pace and controlling where the eyes start/end on a line.
Group the words: Some words like "the world" can be comprehended as one thing instead of reading two words.
This can be practised by grouping words in a book before reading and then trying to read a unit or rather take a unit in as one.
Read in the middle: Try to read the first and last word without focusing on it.
You can exercise it with drawing lines and guiding the focus of your eyes.
Abk√ºrzungen:

wpm = words per minute

item.title: Work together
item.description:
Avoid
fighting on multiple topics at the same time...
Contempt against a person/fighting on personal level
Defensiveness about own fault/responsibility
Stonewalling: completely blocking all criticism/problems
Make a plan!
Divide
define who is responsible for what
so everybody knows, when there is a problem, who is responsible for it/makes the decision
when (the) other person(s) should interfere, what is success/failure
for example in fundraising: successful or failed tu raise enough money
Understand Relationship types
Secure: I don't mind being vulnerable (not that common)
Anxious: I don't get as much love as I want/I want to hold on to other people/I want constant confirmation about me
Avoidant: I find it difficult to build relationships/I'm worried that I mess it up/I need more space for myself/maybe runs away sometimes
Important to know the others type of relationship --> understand differences
talk to each other about your feelings/needs
Create a process for dealing with disagreements

item.title: All-purpose Cleaner with mandarines
item.description:
#example #cleaner #fruit #mandarine #zerowaste
tags: #example #cleaner #fruit #mandarine #zerowaste
overview: if it is a subtopic to a broader topic like a summary note of notes
related:
sources: Greenpeace magazine 2023/1


Cut the mandarin skin in parts and put them in an e.g. jar. Care that the skin is untreated and their is no flesh on them anymore. Then add vinegar.
Keep the mixture during 2-3 weks in a closed glass at a dark place. Keep all of the skin covered with vinegar to avoid mildew.
After three weeks, get the skins out of the liquid. Put it in a screwable bottle and mix some water to it.
Also other citrus fruits are suitable.

item.title: Car driving
item.description:
#Tip #german


Parking card
start at the next half hour
normally for 1 hour

#Tip Controll views before signaling to turn in one direction is like opening a tresor in three steps (or views): The tresor cannot be just opened in two steps, there is no shortcut. Either it is open or still closed.


rear-/exterior mirror/view on the side over your shoulder
set blinker


Some things are quite obvious/clear in retroperspective, but some people still do it (don't know to say names here^^)

You are not allowed to cross them. Image these as walls or spikes. You wouldn't drive in or on such things either.

security lines at crossroads/light signals

The two cases I learnt are using it for turning or driving backwards in such a street.
In both cases be very aware of your surroundings and what's going on behind you.


drive backwards on the side of the opposing traffic bc.
we won't stay there long (just turn), so it's not a problem
we are immediately on the right side, to leave the (side) street again on the right side


drive backwards on the side, where you would also enter when driving ahead bc.
we use this street for longer
don't bother the opposing traffic (otherwise, they would have to drive backwards, too)


don't go over triangles (no precedence signals on the road)
stay on your road line

#german einspuren (not sure, "track in" is the right translation)
view also Blinking

If there is just one way, for all vehicles

stay on your side e.g. don't use the bike road

e.g. straight on and right

completely close the gap to the side you want to go e.g. also the bike road (so there is no )


wait on the side, you won't to go
don't use the bike road, yet


The rear wheels cannot be moved anymore. So if the rear is not good yet, correct it first


go backwards as near as possible on the side you park in (with the rear wheels).
Go forward away a little bit
backwards again

item.title: Creativity
item.description: The practice

item.title: Decision, decide
item.description:
be in a balanced mood (extreme feelings lead to impulsive action and prevent thoroughly thinking)
be clear about what goal and needs (you want) to achieve with it
list all options to reach the goal/needs
reduce it only down (to the realistic ones) in the second step to avoid falling into the habit trap
think about the positive and negative consequences of every option in the long- and short-term
Are you influenced by group/social pressure? The group/majority/society is not always right
Is there time pressure?
Try to get more (enough) time to look at it from different perspectives.
but care to not always put off making the decision
speak with others you trust about your considerations
more information and perspectives (maybe even ideas)
test your gut feeling by e.g.
marking chairs with the different options => sit down on them and think about how it feels if you would have already decided for this option
if you decide for one thing, you miss out on others => check if that prevents you from making a reasonable decision

item.title: Strengthen eye sight a live long
item.description:
#eyesight #eye #habit
tags: #eyesight #eye #habit
overview: if it is a subtopic to a broader topic like a summary note of notes
related:
sources: Neuroscientist: "This Simple Exercise Will Improve Your Eye Vision" | Andrew Huberman

Habits to improve eye sight or at least strengthen it.


A lot of the times we look at (little) screens not far away like the smartphone or laptop. Eye muscles have to tighten up to focus something close to us.

We should go outside and look at the horizon (not focusing on anything specific) for 20-30 minutes every 90 minutes. Every 30 minutes take a break and relax the eye (muscles).

relax eyes every 30 minutes
every 90 minutes take a longer break (preferrable going outside and looing at the landscape around)

Then make smooth pursuit exercises where you move an object e.g. a pen in front of you in shapes e.g. an eight and follow it with your eyes.
Now move the object back and forth and concentrate again to train different muscles in your eye.

make eye training with an object anywhere you are

firewall (maybe also for general, but without great configuration)
honeypots: vulnerable looking systems
attackers should think it is easy to attack them and get trapped into it (instead of attacking your/the reals system)
we can gather information about the attacker/attacks
email with OpenPGP e.g.
mozilla Thunderbird I have never used OpenPGP with Thunderbird before: How do I setup OpenPGP?
browser extension compatible with gmail, outlook, ... Mailvelope


passwords
alphanumeric
unique/don't reuse
maybe use a password manager e.g. Bitwarden
antivirus software
avoiding mails from unknown sources
Tor browser
Be careful see section "Humans"
lock device if away
use secure internet
don't use public/unsecured wlan (without a VPN)
rather use mobile data/connect to hot spot
secure route: change the default password
Upgrades Make upgrade to have the latest and therefore safest version
Backup
more secure email providers like ProtonMail or Tutanota

Are the weakest chainlink. But they are also the best defense!
Don't get tricked by

phishing (email), Vishing (phone/voicecalls), Smishing (SMS)
unfortunately get better in hiding their attentions/fake identity
signs can be (but don't have to):
bad grammar
urgency
winning something (huge)
ask yourself, if this person is normally writing like that
review sender (mail)
double check links (hover over or copy them into a document) before opening them
contact sender (organization) if unsure

All points under "Individuals"

restrict access
Train staff to better understand threats and how to protect against it
set up a security policy
clear expectations on security practices like password requirements, permissions, data management, ...
how to tackle a breach, ...
Communication
like training staff, communicating security policy
set up a chat or email to answer questions

item.title: ssh keys
item.description:
#article #stillToSummarize

How to use ssh-keygen to generate a new SSH key
ssh-keygen -t <algorithm> -b <key-size> -a <iteration> -C "<comment>" -f <file-location> Copy
algorithm: the hashing algorithm to be used to generate the key
key-size: size in bits of key
iteration: how many iterations are used for the password encryption
comment: comment e.g. with mail to know for what or from whom it is used or was generated
file-location: where it shold be stored and how the file should be named (not necessar if just one key is present)
OpenBSD man page for ssh-keygen with description for all options
example
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "you@host" -f ~/.ssh/my_new_id_ed25519 Copy

#article Medium: How to manage multiple ssh keys

ssh_config Linux man page

#stillToSummarize

there are section for changing some options, upgrading to different hashing algorithm, upgrading OpenSSH (and more of course)

item.title: React (Native) Typescript
item.description:
#stackoverflow #stackoverflow #stackoverflow


#stackoverflow How to use children with React Stateless Functional Component in TypeScript?

with React.PropsWithChildren
import React from 'react'; interface MyProps {} function MyComponent(props: React.PropsWithChildren<MyProps>) { return ( <View> {props.children}; </View> ) } Copy

with React.FunctionComponent
import React from 'react'; interface MyProps {}; const MyComponent: React.FunctionComponent<MyProps> = props => { return ( <View> {props.children} </View> ) } Copy


#stackoverflow What is the syntax for Typescript arrow functions with generics?
const myArrowFunction = <T,>(props: myPropsInterface<T>) => { ... } Copy



#stackoverflow got Type 'void' is not assignable to type '() => void' in react typescript
MyComponent.tsx interface Props { functionName: () => void; } ... ---------------------------- MyScreen.tsx handleFunction = () => void <MyComponent functionName={this.handleFunction} /> Copy

here we have the problem, that functionName just "gets" the return value of handleFunction (which is in our case void)
Solution
MyScreen.tsx handleFunction = () => void <MyComponent functionName={() => this.handleFunction} /> Copy

item.title: thermal paste or pad
item.description:
Attention: Thermal pads not reusable and cheaper??? https://nabcooling.com/thermal-pad-everything-you-need-to-know/


For that we need to first know why we even need either of them. First there are more and less efficient material for transferring heat. For example air has around 0.026 W/Km at room temperature which is really little. Metals are much more, around 200 times, heat conductive. And thermal paste can have, depending on the used materials (and so dust the cost), between 3-13 W/Km. Metals are much higher and can have hundreds of W/Km.

The problem is the surface. These metal surfaces, even though they look really flat to our eyes, they aren't at all. So there would be some spikes where metal touches each other but most will be air. This is not good for heat transfering as explained in "Why do we even need either of them?", air is much worse at taking heat. So most heat will be forced to go through the little metal intersections and the chip will overheat fast due to too little heat flow.
There is where thermal paste or pads come in. They remove the air with its better heat conductivity

You can easily cut out the wanted thermal pad, buy the exact height you need for the intersection and even reuse them or don't replace it at least. They are cheaper to get. And last but not least easier to use. There won't be a mess with thermal paste on components you didn't want it to be. So why do we even need thermal paste then?

The advantage thermal paste has, is how much you use of it. As we discussed earlier metal has an even better conductivity rate than thermal paste and pads. So if possible you just want to fill the air spaces with past and let metal touch metal wherever possible. Probably not really practical doable... So the best way is to just put as little paste on the chip as possible. That is not possible with the paste. It can not redistribute itself, there will be the same thickness everywhere.

Use thermal paste when you need as much heat transfer/cooling as possible. But be aware that less can be more. When putting the chip on the cooling pad the paste will "flow" where it is need and not take up more space. Just a tiny surface not allowing air in it.
On the other hand thermal pads are better for covering surfaces which have a greater distance between it and its cooling component. It is use for example on VRAMs where it is more important to have a connection (which is still pretty good, but not "perfect") than cooling as much as possible.

item.title: replacing broken late 20112 iMac gpu
item.description:
Best thermal paste for iMac GPU and vram chips?
Apple designed these GPUs with a 1.5mm gap between the VRAMs and the cooler. So the thermal paste/pads need to fill these gap and it needs a lot of paste for it. This does NOT apply for the main GPU chip, it just needs a little!

item.title: Welcome
item.description: Hello to my library :)
